title: JavaScript Cheatsheet
description: A general-purpose JavaScript quick reference covering syntax, functions, modules, common pitfalls, and day-to-day patterns (browser + Node.js).

categories.title: Basic Functionality
categories.description: Core syntax: variables, types, strings, objects, and basic I/O.

items.title: Variables and types
items.description: Prefer const by default; use let when reassigning. Avoid var in modern JS.

rows: string, number, bigint, boolean, undefined, symbol, null
x == null checks null or undefined

items.title: Strings and template literals
items.description: Use template literals for interpolation and multi-line strings.

items.title: Objects
items.description: Objects are key/value maps. Use optional chaining and nullish coalescing for safer access.
items.example:
const user = { profile: { name: 'Ada' } };
console.log(user.profile?.name ?? 'anonymous');

categories.title: Functions
categories.description: Parameters, returns, scope, anonymous functions, and common built-ins.

items.title: Parameters and returns
items.description: Use default parameters and rest parameters; JS functions can return any value.

items.title: Scope and this
items.description: let/const are block-scoped. Arrow functions capture this lexically; function() has its own this depending on call site.

rows: function declarations hoist; let/const have TDZ

items.title: Anonymous functions
items.description: Use arrow functions for callbacks; name functions when stack traces matter.
items.example: console.log([1,2,3].map(x => x * 2));

items.title: Built-in / predefined functions (common)
items.description: A small sampling of frequently used built-ins and global utilities.
items.example:
const s = '42';
console.log(parseInt(s, 10), Number.isFinite(3.1));

items.title: Array filter/map/reduce
items.description: Prefer pure callbacks; be mindful of performance for very large arrays.

rows: Fold items into a single value

items.title: Parsing and basic validation
items.description: Use Number() for strict-ish conversion; parseInt requires a radix.
items.example:
const n = Number('12');
console.log(Number.isNaN(n) ? 'bad' : n);

categories.title: Globals
categories.description: Global namespaces differ between browser and Node.

items.title: Common globals
items.example: console.log(typeof globalThis, typeof window, typeof process);

categories.title: Packages/Modules
categories.description: ES modules, CommonJS, and package managers.

items.title: ES modules (import/export)
items.description: Modern JS uses ESM. In Node, ESM depends on package.json type or file extension.

items.title: npm basics
items.example:
npm init -y
npm install lodash
node index.js

items.title: Comparisons and null-handling
items.description: Prefer strict equality (===) to avoid type coercion surprises.
items.example:
const x = 0;
console.log(x ?? 10);      // 0
console.log(x || 10);      // 10
console.log(null ?? 'd');  // 'd'

items.title: Spread/rest and destructuring
items.description: Great for copying, merging, and extracting values.

categories.title: Common Errors
categories.description: Frequent runtime errors and environment pitfalls.

items.title: Typical errors

rows: TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined
Using a variable before declaration or not in scope
Invalid JS syntax or JSON parsing

items.title: Array basics
Typed arrays
items.description: For binary data and performance-sensitive numeric work.
items.example:
const bytes = new Uint8Array([65, 66, 67]);
console.log(new TextDecoder().decode(bytes));

items.title: for / for..of / for..in
items.description: Use for..of for arrays/iterables, and for..in for object keys.

items.title: if / else / switch

categories.title: Regular Expressions
categories.description: RegExp is built-in; be aware of flags and escaping.

items.title: RegExp basics

categories.title: Date and Time
categories.description: Use Date for basics; use Intl for formatting; consider libraries for complex time zone work.

items.title: Date basics

categories.title: Database Interactions
categories.description: JavaScript interacts with databases either via backend code (Node) or browser storage (IndexedDB).

items.title: Node.js (typical pattern)
items.description: Use a DB driver (e.g., Postgres, MySQL, SQLite) and parameterized queries.

items.title: Browser: IndexedDB (overview)
items.description: IndexedDB is asynchronous and event-based; wrappers can improve ergonomics.

items.title: Async/await essentials
items.description: Always handle rejections with try/catch or .catch().

items.title: JSON.parse / JSON.stringify
items.description: JSON.parse throws on invalid JSON; JSON.stringify drops functions and symbols.
